mentions.context: This demonstration proposes a fully-distributed PDMS called DISPERS, built on top of SEP2P [11], allowing users to securely and efficiently share and query their personal data.

DISPERS pushes the security level offered by TEEs much further thanks to (1) imposed randomness ensured by the SEP2P protocol [11] -which guarantees that an attacker cannot influence the choice of processing nodes and get more private information than what would be obtained by passively observing the data manipulated by corrupted nodes; and (2) knowledge dispersion and task compartmentalization which reduce the data leakage to a minimum when covert adversaries are (randomly) involved in the query processing.

DISPERS leverages three design principles to securely query the users' data; namely knowledge dispersion to protect data-at-rest, task compartmentalization to protect datain-use, and imposed randomness to assign data processing tasks to PDMS nodes in a verifiable random way, based on SEP2P [11].
